QuestionStem: An animal cell has some of the same structures as a prokaryotic cell, such as a cell membrane and cytoplasm, and some different structures.

content.imageAlt: In this activity, there is an illustration of an animal cell. You can click on the hotspots for more information about the cell's structures and organelles.

panels.title: Nucleus
panels.description: The cell nucleus contains genetic information that gives instructions for making proteins and other materials the cell needs.
panels.imageAlt: This magnified image shows a large, rounded cell organelle that contains a smaller rounded structure.

panels.title: Mitochondrion
panels.description: These organelles convert energy stored in food into a form the cell can use. Cells that need a lot of energy, such as muscle cells, have more mitochondria than do cells that need less energy, such as nerve cells.
panels.imageAlt: This magnified image shows a capsule-shaped organelle with linear internal structures.

panels.title: Rough endoplasmic reticulum (ER)
panels.description: The rough ER is located near the nucleus and contains ribosomes on its surface. It is involved in making and processing proteins.

panels.title: Smooth endoplasmic reticulum (ER)
panels.description: The smooth ER does not contain ribosomes. It makes fat-based molecules, called lipids, that are used to make membranes.

panels.title: Golgi apparatus
panels.description: The Golgi apparatus takes proteins from the ER and moves them to different parts of the cell.

panels.title: Lysosome
panels.description: These structures contain powerful chemicals known as enzymes that break down food.
